abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Access Project (EAP) seeks to
            support economic growth and poverty alleviation, and
            increase the rural and urban populations' access to
            electricity services, ensuring a sustainable supply of
            biomass-based energy. The project will also promote
            least-cost and sustainable solutions, through supply and
            demand-side energy management, and through the participation
            of the private sector and communities. Renewable and low
            carbon energies development will be supported, namely by the
            Global Environment Facility and Carbon finance Credits.
            While the project will seek to avoid as possible, or
            minimize reallocation by evaluating all possible
            alternatives, it is foreseen resettlement will nonetheless
            occur. Involuntary resettlement will be conducted in
            accordance with the Bank's operational directive 4.12,
            specifically targeting the most vulnerable groups, to ensure
            affected people benefit from implementation of the project,
            and that their livelihoods are improved, or at least
            restored. Public consultations will be conducted to inform
            populations on their rights concerning resettlement and
            compensation due. Land replacement shall compensate for land
            losses, while housing and structures will be compensated in
            cash, including construction materials; crop losses - crops
            and fruit trees - will be compensated in kind based on its
            productivity, or, in cash at current market values.
            Grievance mechanisms will be in place should conflict occur.
